i want to add a functionality to my .net library, that when the user compiles it, it generates a special file in the output alongside the .dll that contains metadata that i generate when certain methods and types have an attribute - can i add this with the library itself?
this means the user must add that postbuildevent manually in their csproj´?

Yes, if you're using a post-build event to trigger the metadata generation, the user of your library would need to manually add the post-build event to their project file (`.csproj`).
However, there are ways to automate this process so that the post-build event is added automatically when your library is referenced in another project. Here are a few approaches you can consider:
1. **Use a NuGet package and a targets file**: You can create a NuGet package for your library that includes a `.targets` file. This `.targets` file can be automatically imported into the project file of any project that references your library. Inside the `.targets` file, you can define the post-build event that runs your metadata generator.
2. **Use a source generator**: Starting with .NET 5, you can create a source generator that generates code at compile-time. You can use a source generator to generate a class that runs your metadata generator as a post-build step. This approach doesn't require modifying the project file of the consuming project.
3. **Use a Visual Studio extension**: If your library is primarily targeted at Visual Studio users, you can create a Visual Studio extension that automatically adds the post-build event to the project file when your library is referenced.
4. **Use a project template**: If your library is meant to be used as a starting point for new projects, you can create a project template that includes the post-build event for your metadata generator. When users create a new project from your template, the post-build event will be included automatically.
Each of these approaches has its own advantages and disadvantages, and the best choice depends on your specific use case and the target audience for your library.
Using a NuGet package with a `.targets` file is a common approach, as it allows you to distribute your library and the metadata generation logic together, without requiring users to manually modify their project files. However, it does require some additional setup and packaging steps on your end.
Source generators and Visual Studio extensions provide a more seamless integration experience but may have additional requirements or limitations based on the target framework or development environment.
Project templates can be a good choice if your library is intended to be used as a starting point for new projects, but they may not be as suitable for libraries that are meant to be referenced by existing projects.
Ultimately, the decision will depend on factors such as the target audience for your library, the development environment(s) you need to support, and the level of integration and automation you want to provide for the metadata generation process.
is there a way this can be done automatically with the inclusion of of a library reference?

Yes, there is a way to automatically generate a metadata file when your library is referenced in another project, without requiring the user to manually modify their project file or take any additional steps.
This can be achieved by creating a NuGet package for your library that includes a custom MSBuild targets file. The targets file will be automatically imported into the project file of any project that references your NuGet package, allowing you to define custom build targets and tasks that will run during the build process.
Here's a general outline of the steps you can follow:
1. **Create a custom MSBuild targets file**: Create a file (e.g., `MyLibrary.targets`) that defines a custom target to run your metadata generator. This file should be included in your NuGet package.
```xml <Project> <Target Name="GenerateMetadata" AfterTargets="Build"> <GenerateMetadata AssemblyPath="$(TargetPath)" OutputPath="$(OutputPath)" ProjectDir="$(ProjectDir)" /> </Target>
<UsingTask TaskName="GenerateMetadata" TaskFactory="CodeTaskFactory" AssemblyFile="$(MSBuildToolsPath)\Microsoft.Build.Tasks.Core.dll"> <ParameterGroup> <AssemblyPath ParameterType="System.String" Required="true" /> <OutputPath ParameterType="System.String" Required="true" /> <ProjectDir ParameterType="System.String" Required="true" /> </ParameterGroup> <Task> <!-- Code to run your metadata generator --> </Task> </UsingTask> </Project> ```
2. **Include the targets file in your NuGet package**: When creating your NuGet package, include the `MyLibrary.targets` file in the `build` folder of your package. This will ensure that the targets file is automatically imported into the project file of any project that references your NuGet package.
3. **Implement the metadata generator logic**: In the `<Task>` section of the `GenerateMetadata` task, implement the logic to scan the assembly for types and methods decorated with your custom attribute, generate the metadata, and write it to the specified output path.
When a project references your NuGet package, the `MyLibrary.targets` file will be automatically imported into the project file, and the `GenerateMetadata` target will be executed after the build process completes. This target will run your metadata generator, passing in the necessary information (assembly path, output path, project directory) as parameters.
By using this approach, you can ensure that the metadata generation process is automatically triggered whenever your library is referenced in another project, without requiring the user to manually modify their project file or take any additional steps.
Note that this approach assumes that you have control over the NuGet package creation process for your library. If you're distributing your library through a different mechanism (e.g., a binary distribution), you may need to explore alternative methods for automatically integrating the metadata generation process.
couldnt a source generator work for this?
how do i implement a source generator
so when is this source generator run

A source generator is run during the compilation process of the project that references your library containing the source generator. Specifically, the source generator is executed as part of the Roslyn code analysis phase, which occurs before the actual compilation of the code.
Here's a breakdown of when the source generator is executed:
1. **Project Build**: When a project that references your library is built, the build process starts.
2. **Roslyn Code Analysis**: During the build process, the Roslyn compiler performs code analysis on the project's source code. This includes parsing the code, building syntax trees, and performing semantic analysis.
3. **Source Generator Execution**: As part of the code analysis phase, the Roslyn compiler looks for any registered source generators and invokes them. This is where your source generator's `Initialize` and `Execute` methods are called.
- The `Initialize` method is called first, allowing you to set up any necessary state or register for syntax notifications. - The `Execute` method is then called, where you can analyze the syntax trees and generate additional source code based on your logic.
4. **Generated Source Code Injection**: Any source code generated by your source generator is injected into the compilation pipeline, effectively becoming part of the project's source code.
5. **Compilation**: After the source generator has executed and injected any generated code, the Roslyn compiler proceeds with the actual compilation of the project, including the generated source code.
6. **Output Assembly**: Finally, the compiled output assembly is produced, which includes the code from the original project as well as any code generated by the source generator.
It's important to note that source generators are executed for each project that references your library containing the source generator. This means that if multiple projects in a solution reference your library, the source generator will be executed separately for each project during its respective build process.
Additionally, source generators are executed during both incremental and full builds of the project. During incremental builds, the source generator is only executed if there have been changes to the source code or the source generator itself since the last build.
By running during the code analysis phase, source generators can analyze and modify the project's source code before it is compiled, allowing for powerful code generation and transformation capabilities. This makes source generators a powerful tool for generating boilerplate code, implementing code weaving, or performing other code transformations based on the project's source code and your custom logic.

so there is IIncrementalGenerator and ISourceGenerator, are there others? and how do they relate?

In the `Microsoft.CodeAnalysis` namespace, there are two main interfaces related to source generators: `ISourceGenerator` and `IIncrementalGenerator`. These interfaces represent different approaches to implementing source generators, each with its own advantages and use cases.
1. **ISourceGenerator**: - `ISourceGenerator` is the original and simpler interface for implementing source generators. - It provides a straightforward way to generate source code during the compilation process. - Implementations of `ISourceGenerator` must implement two methods: `Initialize` and `Execute`. - The `Execute` method is called once during the compilation process, and the generator has access to the entire syntax tree of the project. - `ISourceGenerator` is suitable for scenarios where the generated code does not depend on incremental changes or when the entire syntax tree needs to be analyzed.
2. **IIncrementalGenerator**: - `IIncrementalGenerator` is a more advanced interface that provides support for incremental source generation. - It allows the generator to respond to changes in the source code and update the generated code accordingly, without having to reanalyze the entire syntax tree. - Implementations of `IIncrementalGenerator` must implement the `Initialize` method and provide an implementation of the `IncrementalGeneratorInitializationContext` class. - The `IncrementalGeneratorInitializationContext` class allows the generator to register for specific syntax node types and receive notifications when those nodes change. - `IIncrementalGenerator` is suitable for scenarios where the generated code depends on specific parts of the source code, and it can be more efficient for large projects or projects with frequent code changes.
In addition to these two interfaces, there are a few other related interfaces and classes in the `Microsoft.CodeAnalysis` namespace:
3. **IncrementalGeneratorBase**: - `IncrementalGeneratorBase` is an abstract base class that provides a default implementation of `IIncrementalGenerator`. - It simplifies the implementation of incremental generators by handling the boilerplate code and providing helper methods for common tasks. - Developers can inherit from `IncrementalGeneratorBase` and override specific methods to implement their custom generator logic.
4. **IncrementalSourceGeneratorBase**: - `IncrementalSourceGeneratorBase` is another abstract base class that provides a higher-level abstraction for implementing incremental source generators. - It builds upon `IncrementalGeneratorBase` and provides additional functionality for generating source code based on syntax nodes. - Developers can inherit from `IncrementalSourceGeneratorBase` and implement methods to handle specific syntax node types and generate the corresponding source code.
The choice between `ISourceGenerator` and `IIncrementalGenerator` (or their respective base classes) depends on the specific requirements of your source generator and the complexity of the code generation logic. If the generated code does not depend on incremental changes or if the entire syntax tree needs to be analyzed, `ISourceGenerator` may be a simpler choice. However, if the generated code depends on specific parts of the source code and needs to be updated incrementally, `IIncrementalGenerator` or its base classes may be more suitable.
It's worth noting that `IIncrementalGenerator` and its related classes are more complex and may have a steeper learning curve compared to `ISourceGenerator`. However, they provide more flexibility and efficiency for scenarios that require incremental code generation.
so is IIncrementalGenerator better for my use-case of generating a txt file (next to the output assembly), based on attributes in the source?

For the use case of generating a text file (or any file) next to the output assembly based on attributes in the source code, the `ISourceGenerator` interface would likely be a better choice than `IIncrementalGenerator`.
Here's why `ISourceGenerator` is a more suitable option for this scenario:
1. **Simplicity**: `ISourceGenerator` is a simpler interface to implement compared to `IIncrementalGenerator`. Since you're not dealing with incremental changes or updating the generated code based on specific syntax node changes, the simpler `ISourceGenerator` interface should be sufficient.
2. **One-time generation**: In your use case, you need to generate the text file only once during the compilation process, based on the attributes present in the source code. `ISourceGenerator` is designed for this kind of one-time generation scenario, where the generator has access to the entire syntax tree and can analyze it to generate the desired output.
3. **No need for incremental updates**: Since you're generating a text file and not modifying the source code itself, there's no need for incremental updates or responding to specific syntax node changes. `IIncrementalGenerator` is more suitable when you need to update the generated code based on incremental changes in the source code.
4. **Easier to implement**: Implementing `ISourceGenerator` is generally easier than implementing `IIncrementalGenerator`, especially for simpler use cases like yours. `IIncrementalGenerator` involves more complex setup and handling of incremental changes, which may not be necessary for your scenario.
However, if your requirements change in the future and you need to generate or update the text file based on specific syntax node changes or incremental changes in the source code, then `IIncrementalGenerator` might become a more suitable choice. But for your current use case of generating a text file based on attributes in the source code, `ISourceGenerator` should be a simpler and more straightforward option.
To implement your use case with `ISourceGenerator`, you can follow these steps:
1. Create a new project for your source generator. 2. Implement a class that inherits from `ISourceGenerator`. 3. In the `Execute` method, analyze the syntax tree to find types or methods with your custom attribute. 4. Generate the content for the text file based on the information from the attributes. 5. Use the `GeneratorExecutionContext` to create the text file in the output directory of the project being built.
By using `ISourceGenerator`, you can keep your implementation simple and focused on the specific task of generating a text file based on attributes in the source code.

Alright, my issue: Im making a library, that provides attributes. This library then needs to have an agnostic execution "injection", as in, when any implementing Project builds, or compiles, this code is executed in the library - the library then uses the new execution context to see if the implementing project added those attributes anywhere and generate a meta data file and place it in the output directory. what are my options?

To achieve what you described, you have a few options:
1. Source Generators (C# 9.0+): - Source Generators are a feature introduced in C# 9.0 that allows you to generate additional source code during compilation. - You can create a Source Generator in your library that inspects the compilation context, looks for the attributes you defined, and generates the metadata file accordingly. - The generated metadata file will be included in the output directory of the implementing project. - This approach requires the implementing project to use C# 9.0 or later and have the necessary NuGet package references to enable Source Generators.
2. Roslyn Analyzers: - Roslyn Analyzers are a way to analyze and generate code during the compilation process. - You can create a Roslyn Analyzer in your library that analyzes the syntax tree of the implementing project, identifies the usage of your attributes, and generates the metadata file. - The analyzer can be distributed as a NuGet package and referenced by the implementing project. - When the implementing project is compiled, the analyzer will run and generate the metadata file in the output directory.
3. Build Tasks or Targets: - You can create custom MSBuild tasks or targets in your library that are executed during the build process of the implementing project. - These tasks or targets can scan the project's source files, look for the attributes, and generate the metadata file. - The generated metadata file can be placed in the output directory using MSBuild properties and tasks. - This approach requires the implementing project to include the necessary build targets or tasks from your library.
4. Runtime Reflection: - If generating the metadata file at compile-time is not a strict requirement, you can use runtime reflection to scan the types in the implementing project's assembly. - Your library can provide a method or API that the implementing project calls at runtime to generate the metadata file based on the attributes found through reflection. - This approach does not require any compile-time code generation but relies on runtime execution.
Each approach has its own advantages and considerations. Source Generators and Roslyn Analyzers provide compile-time code generation, while build tasks/targets and runtime reflection offer more flexibility but may have some performance impact.
Consider your specific requirements, the target frameworks you need to support, and the ease of integration for the implementing projects when choosing the most suitable approach for your library.
elaborate on the build target approach, how would that look like?

Certainly! Let's dive into the build target approach in more detail.
In this approach, you create custom MSBuild targets in your library that are executed during the build process of the implementing project. These targets scan the project's source files, look for the attributes, and generate the metadata file.
Here's a high-level overview of how it would look like:
1. Create a new class library project for your library.
2. Define your custom attributes in the library project.
3. Create an MSBuild targets file (e.g., `YourLibrary.targets`) in your library project. This file will contain the custom build targets.
4. In the targets file, define a new target (e.g., `GenerateMetadata`) that will be executed during the build process.
5. Inside the `GenerateMetadata` target, use MSBuild tasks to scan the project's source files and look for the usage of your custom attributes. You can use tasks like `Csc` or `ReadLinesFromFile` to read the source files and analyze their content.
6. When you find the attributes in the source files, generate the metadata file using the information obtained from the attributes. You can use MSBuild tasks like `WriteLinesToFile` to create the metadata file.
7. Use MSBuild properties and tasks to specify the output directory where the generated metadata file should be placed (e.g., `$(OutputPath)`).
8. Package your library along with the targets file into a NuGet package.
9. In the implementing project, reference the NuGet package of your library.
10. The implementing project's build process will automatically pick up the custom build targets from your library and execute them during the build.
Here's a simplified example of how the targets file (`YourLibrary.targets`) might look like:
```xml <Project> <Target Name="GenerateMetadata" BeforeTargets="BeforeBuild"> <ItemGroup> <SourceFiles Include="$(MSBuildProjectDirectory)\**\*.cs" /> </ItemGroup>
<ReadLinesFromFile File="%(SourceFiles.Identity)"> <Output TaskParameter="Lines" ItemName="SourceLines" /> </ReadLinesFromFile>
<!-- Analyze the source lines and generate the metadata file --> <GenerateMetadataTask SourceLines="@(SourceLines)" OutputFile="$(OutputPath)\Metadata.xml" /> </Target> </Project> ```
In this example, the `GenerateMetadata` target is defined to run before the `BeforeBuild` target. It uses the `ReadLinesFromFile` task to read the source files and passes the lines to a custom task called `GenerateMetadataTask` (which you would need to implement in your library). The custom task analyzes the source lines, looks for the attributes, and generates the metadata file (`Metadata.xml`) in the output directory.
The implementing project doesn't need to do anything special apart from referencing your library's NuGet package. The build targets will be automatically executed during the build process.
Keep in mind that this is a simplified example, and you would need to implement the actual logic for scanning the source files, identifying the attributes, and generating the metadata file based on your specific requirements.
The build target approach provides flexibility and allows you to integrate your library's metadata generation seamlessly into the implementing project's build process.

issue with both source generation and msbuild, it requires nugets that get added to the output, which will then be required by the implementing project, right? or can i suppress the output build and still allow the other proj to work with it?

You're correct that both source generators and MSBuild tasks typically require additional NuGet packages or assemblies that get added to the output of the implementing project. However, there are ways to suppress the output of these additional assemblies while still allowing the implementing project to work with your library.
1. Source Generators: With source generators, you can mark the generator assembly as a `PrivateAsset` in the implementing project's reference to your library. This means that the generator assembly will be used only during compilation and won't be included in the output of the implementing project.
In the implementing project's `.csproj` file, you can add the following reference:
```xml <ItemGroup> <PackageReference Include="YourLibrary" Version="1.0.0"> <PrivateAssets>all</PrivateAssets> </PackageReference> </ItemGroup> ```
By setting `<PrivateAssets>all</PrivateAssets>`, you indicate that the source generator assembly should not be included in the output of the implementing project.
2. MSBuild Tasks: With MSBuild tasks, you can use the `<Private>` element in the implementing project's reference to your library to control whether the task assembly is copied to the output directory.
In the implementing project's `.csproj` file, you can add the following reference:
```xml <ItemGroup> <PackageReference Include="YourLibrary" Version="1.0.0"> <Private>false</Private> </PackageReference> </ItemGroup> ```
By setting `<Private>false</Private>`, you prevent the task assembly from being copied to the output directory of the implementing project.
Additionally, you can use the `<ExcludeAssets>` element to specify that the task assembly should be excluded from the output:
```xml <ItemGroup> <PackageReference Include="YourLibrary" Version="1.0.0"> <ExcludeAssets>runtime</ExcludeAssets> </PackageReference> </ItemGroup> ```
By setting `<ExcludeAssets>runtime</ExcludeAssets>`, you exclude the task assembly from the runtime output of the implementing project.
In both cases, the source generator or MSBuild task will still execute during the compilation or build process of the implementing project, but the additional assemblies won't be included in the final output.
It's important to note that if your library itself contains runtime components that the implementing project needs to reference, you should package them separately from the source generator or MSBuild task assemblies. This way, the implementing project can reference the runtime components while excluding the build-time assemblies from the output.
By using these techniques, you can suppress the output of the additional assemblies required by source generators or MSBuild tasks while still allowing the implementing project to work with your library seamlessly.

To generate a package with everything combined, you can modify your project file (`.csproj`) to include the necessary configuration for packaging. Here's an example of how you can modify the `<PropertyGroup>` section to achieve this:
```xml <PropertyGroup> <RootNamespace>TeleCore.Patching</RootNamespace> <AssemblyName>TeleCore.Patching</AssemblyName> <TargetFramework>net6.0</TargetFramework> <GeneratePackageOnBuild>true</GeneratePackageOnBuild> <PackageId>TeleCore.Patching</PackageId> <Version>1.0.0</Version> <Authors>Your Name</Authors> <Company>Your Company</Company> <Description>A library for patching and code generation.</Description> <PackageOutputPath>$(MSBuildThisFileDirectory)bin\$(Configuration)\</PackageOutputPath> </PropertyGroup> ```
Let's go through the added properties:
- `<TargetFramework>`: Specifies the target framework for your library. In this example, it's set to `net6.0`, but you can change it based on your requirements.
- `<GeneratePackageOnBuild>`: Set this to `true` to automatically generate a NuGet package when the project is built.
- `<PackageId>`: Specifies the unique identifier for your NuGet package. It should match your library's name.
- `<Version>`: Specifies the version number of your NuGet package.
- `<Authors>`: Specifies the authors of your library.
- `<Company>`: Specifies the company or organization associated with your library.
- `<Description>`: Provides a description for your library.
- `<PackageOutputPath>`: Specifies the output path where the generated NuGet package will be placed. In this example, it's set to the `bin\$(Configuration)\` directory relative to the project file.
With these modifications, when you build your project, it will generate a NuGet package that includes your library, along with any additional files specified in your project file.
To include additional files in the package, you can use the `<ItemGroup>` element. For example, to include your MSBuild targets file (`YourLibrary.targets`) in the package, you can add the following:
```xml <ItemGroup> <None Include="YourLibrary.targets" Pack="true" PackagePath="build\" /> </ItemGroup> ```
This includes the `YourLibrary.targets` file in the package and places it in the `build\` directory within the package.
After building your project, you'll find the generated NuGet package in the specified output path (`bin\$(Configuration)\` in this example).
You can then distribute this NuGet package to the implementing projects, and they can reference it to utilize your library's functionality, including any code generation or patching capabilities.
Remember to adjust the property values and include any additional files or dependencies specific to your library.
in c#, since structs cannot inherit each other, what would be the usual correct approach to link "base properties" of one struct for another struct to also contain and inherit?

Yes, the approach you've shown is a good setup for a data-oriented IMGUI layout using structs and composition. Let's break it down:
1. You have an `IUIElement` interface that defines a common property `ID` that all UI elements should have.
2. The `UIElementS` struct implements the `IUIElement` interface and contains the actual implementation of the `ID` property. This struct serves as the base struct that other UI element structs can include as a field.
3. The `UIButtonMenu` struct represents a button menu UI element. It includes an instance of `UIElementS` as a field named `_base`. By doing this, `UIButtonMenu` inherits the `ID` property from `UIElementS` through composition.
4. Similarly, the `UITopBar` struct represents a top bar UI element and also includes an instance of `UIElementS` as a field, inheriting the `ID` property.
5. The `UIButtonMenu` struct has a method `AddButton` that takes a label and a click action as parameters. This method allows you to add buttons to the button menu.
6. The `UITopBar` struct has a method `AddMenu` that takes a label as a parameter and returns a `UIButtonMenu`. This method allows you to add button menus to the top bar.
This setup provides a clean and structured way to define UI elements using structs and composition. The `UIElementS` struct acts as a base struct that contains common properties, and other UI element structs include it as a field to inherit those properties.
By using structs instead of classes, you can achieve better performance and memory efficiency, especially when dealing with a large number of UI elements. Structs are value types and are allocated on the stack, which can lead to faster memory allocation and deallocation compared to classes.
However, it's important to note that structs should be kept relatively small and focused on representing data rather than containing complex behavior. If you find yourself adding a lot of methods or complex logic to your structs, it might be a sign that you should consider using classes instead.
Overall, your approach of using structs, composition, and an interface for a data-oriented IMGUI layout is a good choice, as it promotes a clean and efficient structure for your UI elements.
what is webassembly and how does it differ from compiling something like .Net exe

WebAssembly (Wasm) is a low-level, assembly-like language that runs in modern web browsers. It is designed to be a portable target for compilation of high-level languages like C, C++, and Rust, enabling those programs to run on the web at near-native speed.
Here are the key differences between WebAssembly and compiling a .NET executable:
1. Execution Environment: - WebAssembly: Runs inside a web browser's virtual machine, alongside JavaScript. It is executed in a sandboxed environment, providing security and isolation from the host system. - .NET Executable: Runs directly on the operating system, either with the support of the .NET runtime (for managed code) or as a standalone native executable (for self-contained deployments).
2. Language Support: - WebAssembly: Supports languages that can be compiled to WebAssembly, such as C, C++, Rust, and languages that have WebAssembly backends, like Go and Java. - .NET Executable: Primarily supports languages that target the .NET platform, such as C#, F#, and Visual Basic.
3. Performance: - WebAssembly: Provides near-native performance in the browser. It is faster than JavaScript for computationally intensive tasks but may have some overhead due to the browser's sandboxing and communication with JavaScript. - .NET Executable: Runs at native speed on the operating system, with the performance characteristics of the .NET runtime or native code execution.
4. Portability: - WebAssembly: Highly portable across different web browsers and platforms. WebAssembly modules can run on any browser that supports the WebAssembly standard. - .NET Executable: Portable within the .NET ecosystem. .NET executables can run on any platform that has the .NET runtime installed or can be self-contained with the necessary runtime dependencies.
5. Deployment: - WebAssembly: Deployed as part of a web application. WebAssembly modules are typically loaded and executed by JavaScript code in a web page. - .NET Executable: Deployed as a standalone executable file or as part of an application package. It can be distributed and installed on target systems.
6. Ecosystem and Libraries: - WebAssembly: Has a growing ecosystem with libraries and frameworks specifically designed for WebAssembly, such as Emscripten and Blazor. However, it may have limitations compared to the extensive .NET ecosystem. - .NET Executable: Benefits from the rich .NET ecosystem, including a wide range of libraries, frameworks, and tools specifically built for .NET development.
In summary, WebAssembly is a low-level language that enables running high-performance code in web browsers, while .NET executables are compiled programs that run directly on the operating system using the .NET runtime. WebAssembly focuses on web-based execution and portability, while .NET executables leverage the .NET ecosystem and provide native performance on the target platform.
"Extism" promises to allow running any code in any other codebase, like C# in Zig, by turning it all to webassembly, how would that differ from writing a c# app that painstakingly binds Zig

Extism is a framework that aims to simplify the process of integrating code written in different programming languages into a single application by leveraging WebAssembly. It differs from writing a C# app that manually binds to Zig code in several ways:
1. Language Agnostic: - Extism: Allows you to integrate code written in various programming languages into your application without the need for language-specific bindings. It supports a wide range of languages, including C, C++, Rust, Go, C#, and more. - Manual Binding: Requires writing language-specific bindings to integrate Zig code into a C# app. You would need to manually define the interface and create the necessary glue code to communicate between C# and Zig.
2. Simplified Integration: - Extism: Provides a unified and simplified approach to integrate code modules written in different languages. It abstracts away the complexities of language interoperability by compiling the code to WebAssembly and providing a consistent interface for interaction. - Manual Binding: Involves a more complex and time-consuming process of manually creating bindings, marshaling data between languages, and handling memory management.
3. Performance: - Extism: Compiles the code modules to WebAssembly, which offers near-native performance. WebAssembly is designed to be fast and efficient, providing good performance characteristics across different platforms. - Manual Binding: The performance of manually bound Zig code in a C# app depends on the efficiency of the binding mechanism and the overhead of cross-language communication. It may require careful optimization to achieve optimal performance.
4. Portability: - Extism: Enables the creation of portable and platform-independent code modules. WebAssembly modules can run in various environments, including web browsers, server-side runtimes, and embedded systems. - Manual Binding: The portability of manually bound Zig code in a C# app is limited to platforms that support both C# and Zig. It may require additional effort to ensure compatibility across different platforms.
5. Ecosystem and Tooling: - Extism: Provides a growing ecosystem and tooling support for integrating different languages through WebAssembly. It offers tools and libraries to facilitate the compilation, loading, and execution of WebAssembly modules. - Manual Binding: Relies on the ecosystem and tooling specific to C# and Zig. You would need to use the respective compilers, build systems, and tools for each language separately.
While writing a C# app that manually binds to Zig code gives you fine-grained control over the integration process, it requires more effort, expertise, and maintenance compared to using a framework like Extism. Extism aims to simplify the process of integrating code written in different languages by leveraging WebAssembly as a common runtime and providing a unified interface for interaction.
However, it's worth noting that Extism is a relatively new framework, and its maturity, performance, and ecosystem support may not be as extensive as established language-specific binding mechanisms. The choice between using Extism or manually binding Zig code in a C# app depends on factors such as the complexity of the integration, performance requirements, and the specific needs of your project.

its probably due to me publicizing everything in Harmony, how do I exclude that type? This doesnt seem to work:
<DoNotPublicize Include="0Harmony:System.Span"/>

To exclude the `System.Span<Color>` type from being publicized by Harmony, you can use the `DoNotPublicize` element in your Harmony configuration. However, the syntax you provided is slightly incorrect. Here's the correct way to exclude the type:
```xml <DoNotPublicize Include="System.Span`1[[System.Drawing.Color, System.Drawing]]" /> ```
Explanation: - `System.Span`1` represents the generic type `System.Span<T>`. - `[[System.Drawing.Color, System.Drawing]]` specifies the type argument `System.Drawing.Color` and the assembly where it is defined (`System.Drawing`).
Make sure to include this `DoNotPublicize` element in your Harmony configuration file (e.g., `HarmonyManifest.xml` or `App.config`) under the appropriate section.
Here's an example of how it would look in an `App.config` file:
```xml <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <configuration> <runtime> <Harmony> <DoNotPublicize Include="System.Span`1[[System.Drawing.Color, System.Drawing]]" /> </Harmony> </runtime> </configuration> ```
By adding this configuration, Harmony will exclude the `System.Span<Color>` type from being publicized, which should resolve the ambiguous reference error you encountered.
If you still face issues after adding the `DoNotPublicize` element, you can try the following alternative approaches:
1. Use a fully qualified type name in your code: ```csharp global::System.Span<global::System.Drawing.Color> ```
2. Use an alias directive to create a unique alias for the type: ```csharp using ColorSpan = System.Span<System.Drawing.Color>; ```
Then use `ColorSpan` in your code instead of `System.Span<Color>`.
These alternative approaches can help disambiguate the type reference if the `DoNotPublicize` configuration doesn't resolve the issue.
i want to not include any Span

If you want to exclude all `System.Span<T>` types from being publicized by Harmony, regardless of the type argument, you can use a wildcard (`*`) in the `DoNotPublicize` element. Here's how you can modify the configuration:
```xml <DoNotPublicize Include="System.Span`1[[*]]" /> ```
Explanation: - `System.Span`1` represents the generic type `System.Span<T>`. - `[[*]]` is a wildcard that matches any type argument.
By using the wildcard `*`, Harmony will exclude all instances of `System.Span<T>`, regardless of the specific type argument.
Here's an example of how it would look in an `App.config` file:
```xml <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <configuration> <runtime> <Harmony> <DoNotPublicize Include="System.Span`1[[*]]" /> </Harmony> </runtime> </configuration> ```
With this configuration, Harmony will not publicize any `System.Span<T>` types, which should resolve the ambiguous reference error for all instances of `System.Span<T>`.
If you encounter any further issues or the wildcard approach doesn't work as expected, you can try using a more specific exclusion pattern. For example:
```xml <DoNotPublicize Include="System.Span`1" /> ```
This pattern will exclude all `System.Span<T>` types without specifying any type arguments.
Remember to place the `DoNotPublicize` element in the appropriate section of your Harmony configuration file (`HarmonyManifest.xml` or `App.config`).
If the issue persists, you may need to investigate further to identify any other potential conflicts or dependencies related to `System.Span<T>` in your project.
